comments.text: can you give a break down of the hardware size requirements for this? I am buying new fans so I only need the diameter and how far they go into the mount plus any other hardware required to mount it.
comments.author: Ironpepsi

comments.text:
Hi,
This is what I used for fixating the various components.
The 30mm fan is fixed by 4x M3x12mm (DIN912). The 40mm fan is fixed by 4x M4x16 screws (DIN912).
The E3D clamp part will be fixed with 6x countersunk (CS) M4x12 screws (DIN7991/ISO10642).
The mounting holes don't have any thread when printed but the thread will be formed by placing the screws
The belt clamps are fixed with 4x M3 Nut (DIN 934) and 4x CS M3x8 (DIN7991/ISO10642)

title: Orange Pi Zero Case with Fan Grille And Buck Converter Provision

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad.

OrangePi Zero (AUD$13) running Debian Jessie, OPi-Monitor and OctoPrint.

SY-DC3003 Buck Converter. Adjust output for 5v for the OrangePi. Connect via the 5v and GND pins on the header.

Edit: Looks like these Buck Converters are no longer available. :-( I'll have to get a current popular model and redesign the case. Later! :-)

Edit2: Just bought 5 of these for $4 and when they arrive i'll do a new case. :-) https://www.aliexpress.com/item/15924-Free-shipping-DC-DC-Step-Down-Converter-Module-LM2596-DC-4-0-40-to-1/32354635261.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.wYuLyC

30mm x 10mm fan. 12v or 5v. Whatever works for you.

Made to mount on a 20x20 extrusion with T-Nuts.

Remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2783689 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2217389

Pictures added :-)

Added the missing piece! :-)

Added STLs for LM2596 Buck Converter. I haven't printed this as I don't have my "modern" buck converters yet, but hey, if you want, give it a bash! :-) I used this model as a template to add the LM2596 provision to the case. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2156429 :-)

Re-organised the file names so they made more sense. Made the mounting plate for the 20x20 attachment a bit thicker.

17/2/2018 Added a new version of the bigger case that has the holes for both the SY-DC3003 and LM2596 Buck Converters. Printed it and the top clips onto the bottom perfectly. Added a couple more pictures.

description.text:
A work in progress dragonfly automata I was initially working on for a small project in my SolidWorks class. More .STLs of the prototypes to follow. 

In bending the wire for the axle I found that the requisit tolerances were tighter than I could achieve with the spring wire and needlenose pliers I was using. In later iterations I will try a different method of bending as well as a thinner/more readily bent wire. Acetone was used to finish and join parts through solvent welding. Wire was heat-set into pre printed holes in ABS parts.

title: Heatbed Cable Holder for Prusa-like Routing

description.text:
I made this cable holder to be able to route the cable of the heatbed like at the original Prusa i3 mk2 and mk3. Here the connection of the heatbed is at the left corner, this makes it more easyly possible to route the cable backwards to the elecronics box.
I did not include a spring for the heatbed because I have a level sensor and don't need to level the bed manually.
Use 100% Infill and Supports. Also you need a temperature stable filament like PETG, PLA will not work due to the hot heatbed.

description.text:
I made this in Sketchup after really liking the original design of this webcam mount. The "Universal" aspect of it is if your camera uses a standard tripod mount, like my Logitech C615 does. I tried to keep it simple to print by making it mostly just rectangles, however the screw threads are a little hard to clean the supports off of.
After cleaning up the threads on the support side you just start screwing your camera in and it goes right on and snug.

If you have any suggestions on a better way to print the screw threads, let me know, I'm just beginning.

Props to the original designer that this is based off of.

description.text:
9x19mm Parabellum Cartridge - 2piece

It's a simple 2 piece high poly model made to real life scale. Model comes in 2 pieces, bullet and the casing.
If printed correctly then they should fit together just fine but as they are separate pieces you can easily scale one of them slighty up or down if needed.
Once the 2 pieces are put together the cartridge length should be around 2.9 - 3mm

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Walls on the top part of the case are thinner than 0.4mm which means you have to lower your extrusion width maybe as low as 0.3mm. If you don't then the slicing software will not even recognize part of the model at 100% scale unless your nozzle diametre is 0.3 - 0.35mm.

Also make sure that your bed is not too warm or the bottom layers are not too wide because then the bullet may not fit in the casing without having to trim the bottom edge of the bullet.

The mount includes a bottom opening for the charger cord, earbuds, and built-in speaker; as clear access to the Home button; and a chamfered hole to accommodate a standard wall screw. It is sized to hold an iPhone 6/6S with a Spigen Neo Hybrid case (approx 145x75x10mm) with a little bit of room to spare. I've included an export of the model in STEP & Solidworks formats and can also provide a link to the OnShape cloud location in case anyone would like to customize the design.

title: PS Vita Charging Dock Stand (Recessed Logo)

description.text:
Remix of my other stand that had the logo extruding from the front.
This one was made with Hatchbox wood PLA. I really love this stuff.

I took the PS Vita Stand by LordLeXaT and cleaned up the front and added a different PS Vita logo, then cut out a 2-stage channel down the center and added a channel to run the cord. The bottom half of the hole is large enough for the USB tip to fit through, but only the top half will fit the Playstation end of the cord, so it will sit high enough up for the dock to make a connection.
I used a brim to guarantee flat corners but no other support was needed.

title: GoPro Piper Cherokee PA-28 Under Wing Tie Down Mount

description.text:
I created this 'under-wing gopro mount' for a Piper Cherokee PA-28 using the design by @bovine as inspiration. This mounts directly over the under wing tie-down (left or right) and holds a GoPro securely in place during flight. It also always for about 90 degree of adjustment of the GoPro. There are 5mm nut (gopro standard) holder so you don't need a wrench to install when using standard GoPro screw knobs.

I will post more pictures and video after I take it up for a test run!

Printed in Hatchbox Carbon Fiber PLA. The knobs were printed with Hatchbox yellow. Knob design 'Gopro knob short' by julien9462.

comments.text: Nice remix! You might want to be cautious and check the strength of your prints since the layer orientation might cause reduced strength, possibly breaking off and dropping your GoPro.

author: glatzy91

description.text:
Those LEGO Mecanum Wheels will provide omnidirectional capabilities to your four-wheel drive LEGO robot.

Each wheel requires two rims (of same side), and six rollers.

Rubber coating the rollers for extra adherence
  1. Find some liquide PLASTI DIP Multi-Purpose Rubber Coating
  2. Insert a cross axle to avoid coating inside the rollers
  3. Dip rollers and hang to dry
  4. When dry, trim excess coating using a knife or a file
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/KzzyP--GHpM" ></iframe>
I built a simple structure between the two rims (in addition to only a cross axle) to ensure firm alignment of the two rims and prevent the rollers from falling off.

comments.text: How stable is driving side ways? Could you please, share a bit more details on assembly of the wheel?
comments.author: dragoncube

comments.text:
Hi! Thank you for your interest!
Driving is as stable no matter the direction, thanks to the circular and continuous profile. Of course, the print quality plays. Here is a closer look in action.
And good point, I provided assembly STL file and pictures for a better look.

author: yerand

description.text: This is a model of the WOPR computer from War Games. The model was manually reconstructed by watching the same 39 seconds of the film over and over again. I took a few liberties in the rebuild. (1) The recessed hatches and/or the overall length are not quite to scale (there actually should be a group of four rivets after the pair of panels). (2) The real movie prop has a bit of an overhang at the floor, whereas I made the sides go straight down to the floor for easier MakerBot and RepRap printing. (3) I made no attempt to model das blinkenlights. (4) I only reproduced the large text. (5) There may be an Easter Egg inside the hollow base for fans of TRON. Slightly more detail on my blog: http://netninja.com/2012/08/03/is-that-a-wopr-in-your-pocket/

Print and enjoy, but do not start any global thermonuclear wars.  
On a home 3D printer, you will absolutely have problems with the overhang, but a hobby knife and file should clean it up enough to be somewhat presentable.
A solid version of the model, without the TRON easter egg, is also attached.

author: Slider235

description.text: customized with 3D Slash!

When working though y-axis layer shift issues I designed this model to excite my particular failure mode (basically circular shapes seemed more likely cause my printer to fail). Probably won't be effective in all failure scenarios, 'but something to try. For me it failed 100% of the time for what had been a frustratingly intermittent issue previously.

Suggest you align it so the smallest and central ellipses lie along the y-axis, turn the layer height down as far as possible (more layers = more chances to shift), use no top layers, thicker walls (I used 5), and line infill (at 0 and 135 degrees).

I also suggest using a brim to keep it on the build plate, it was really designed with that in mind.

Please leave a comment if it works for you. Pointers to other models that reliably fall would be welcome too.

2-20-18 - added a second y-axis test model (Y-Axis-Test_2.stl) I had attempted earlier at the request of a friend. This did NOT fail for me but might be something else to try. Suggest using, minimum layer height, linear infill along the y-axis (as shown in the image), no top or bottom layers, 2 copies, 1 at each end of the y-axis so the travel speed can be fully stimulated.

comments.text: In my case I had to both up the Vref to the y-motor stepper driver chip (e.g. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kkjwOxDSCiQ) AND implement a better cooling solution for the motor driver chips (I suspect the higher Vref lead to thermal issues on the chips). I replaced the 40mm fan on my ramps board with 120mm fan (hoping it was overkill) and added heat sinks (these: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007XACV8O/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) to the motor driver chips. I'll post my 120mm fan bracket but it's for the Tevo electronics box so it may not be relevant to you.

description.text:
I made this pegboard "tile" as a practice piece to start learning Autodesk Fusion 360.

It has standard pegboard spacing and dimensions, with 4 mounting standoffs that have a counter-bore meant for using drywall screws to mount it to a solid surface. If you print several, they can be tiled together - although the sizing is not right for a 2-peg bracket to span two tiles.

Creator Pro

15%

Notes:

It's thin and wide, so curling/warping during the print is a possibility. I've had best results with the bed heated to about 85C. If it does warp, it can still be used since mounting it flattens it out.

Autodesk Fusion 360

(All measurements in inches, sorry)

  • Started with a box, sized 5.75 x 5.75 x .125 inches.
  • Then I created a hole 0.25 diameter in the upper left corner
  • Used the Pattern tool with the hole, creating 6 x 6 holes with 1 inch spacing.
  • Added 4 Cylinders 0.5 x 0.5 inches (added one at a time)
  • Added a hole 0.25 diameter, 0.625 deep in each cylinder
  • Added a hole 0.4 diameter, 0.15 deep on the face of the other side over each cylinder for the counter-bore.

remixed_from.title: Simplified E3D V6 compatible X carriage for 3Dtje Mini 3D Printer

title: Simplified E3D V6 compatible X carriage for 3Dtje Mini 3D Printer- Remixed with endstop support

description.text:
As I don't own stepper drivers that are fancy enough to run without endstops, I've modified part of fiveseven808's improved 3dtje x carriage to incorporate a x-carriage screw (specifically an M3x20) provision, thus (hopefully) allowing an X-axis endstop to be used (the positioning of the screw is based on that on the original 3dtje design, albeit only roughly). The new part works with the original "hotend_v2_cut_standalone.stl" provided in fiveseven808's design, and replaces the second half of the hotend mount provided in the "hotend_v2_cut.stl" file

Please note that while the mount has been tested with a E3D V6 hotend for fit (as pictured), and successfully at that (it's not a perfect fit, but neither was the original design) this has not been tested on an actual 3dtje yet, as mine's only half-finished. Thus while it will probably work, I can't be certain just yet. I have also included the FreeCAD file used to design it if anybody wishes to improve on the existing design.

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Supports:

No

Infill:

40%

Notes:

It may be a better idea to flip the model over the other way as there is a slight overhang due to the larger holes on the bottom of the part, which for me caused a slight amount of sagging, requiring a small amount of filing post print.

The material I used was 3DPrima blue PLA, but I don't see why any other brands wouldn't work.
Some filing may be required (mine was a bit of a tight fit in regards to getting the hotend into the groove in the mount, and there were the aforementioned issues with sagging)

comments.text: Actually, I use normal stepper drivers (a4988s then upgraded to drv8825s for quieter operation) lol. You just need to position the nozzle at 0,0,0 before every print (and make sure that marlin things the coordinates zero out as well, usually requiring a restart after a print). But thanks for the confirmation that this style might be what people want :) I've gone and created a new version of this that has been tested on the 3Dtje! Thanks!

title: Magnetic Stop / Kill switch top Leonelli Apico Jitsie

description.text:
A spare or replacement top cap for Leonelli magnetic Stop / Kill switch, also sold as Jitsie and Apico I believe. Also fits a generic switch bought from Ebay.

Requires a 10mm dia x 5mm high magnet (or 10x3 works, just put a couple of mm of filling behind it).
Accepts standard 10mm flat boot laces for the lanyard (melt the surface of a 25mm length at each end with a soldering iron or lighter and fuse the flat surfaces together to join)
Includes a bead to tighten lanyard around your wrist.

Insert your magnet carefully, keeping it straight. Once pushed home a quick heat with a lighter or soldering iron etc. will allow the lip to be pushed over to hold it in place.
NOTE: the orientation of the magnet is important for the switch to work, check your switch before inserting magnet. My Leonelli and Ebay switches use opposite polarities.

Wanhao

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Yes

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

70% seemed OK

Notes:

I printed in PLA with a brim to provide enough adhesion.
Supports were from build surface only (or it will fill the lanyard hole).
The bead was a little hard to snap out, but using a small rod it levered out cleanly.

Snap off the raft, supports (the top of the dome has a support, make sure you get it all off) and lever the bead out of the centre.
Probably a good idea to clean-up / chamfer the lip before inserting magnet.

remixed_from.author: carlymx
remixed_from.title: P3 Gold (Prusa) - Black Diamond Bowden E3D v5 Hotend.

title: Black Diamond E3D V6 Fan Shroud Remix

description.text:
It seemed like the Black Diamond E3D mount was never going to adapted for the v6 hot end so I did some crude customizing in Tinkercad. I basically shorted the fan shroud by 7.4mm and lowered the holes on the X-axis moutn where the fan shroud / E3D mount attach to accommodate for the shorter body length of the E3D v6 vs the v5. This seemed to be the easiest way so that the heat block is in the same position and the rest of the pieces remain in tact. I have an Anet A8 so I modified the Anet A8 X bracket. Not sure of the difference since both versions say they are for X-rods that at 45mm apart.

WARNING! I have not tried this yet so use at your own risk!

UPDATE: I started over and I think I got this to be printable. The round part of the fan shroud was so thin it was difficult to get this to work. Also, the original version didn't seem to be fully water tight. So I shored up some spots to fill in any holes I found in the model and I added a couple of additional supports just to make sure this thing didn't fall apart as I pulled it from the printer bed.

I HAD TO USE A BRIM given the thin fan shroud. I couldn't get this to print as that part is so thin and fragile and difficult to get the ABS to stick to the bed on its own with getting pushed by the printhead and distorted. I printed the shroud and the bracket using ABS. I used PLA for the X-axis mount as this doesn't get near the hot end.

Let me know how this works out for you!

UPDATE (TBD) - I didn't have the threaded brass fittings and didn't like the idea of jamming regular M3/4 nuts into round holes (actually had marginal success when I tried). So I made another change to include captive M3 nuts for the optional mounts on the bottom of the front and M4 for the other spots were things were getting "secured/bolted" to the main X-axis plate. You have to use the "Pause at Height" plugin for Cura or similar to stop at 4.0mm (0.8mm / 4 layers then 3.2mm for the nut) and 19.2mm so the print will stop at these layers and let you drop / push the nuts into the model before printing is resumed. Be very careful not to move the print bed when doing this which can be a bit tricky because I made the space for the nuts a fairly tight fit.

RECOMMENDATION: I would print the X-axis carriage at at least 40% and 5 perimeters (1.0mm walls with 0.2mm layer height) to make sure there is enough strength and durability. The design is quite intricate in spots and I have broken this when pulling off the build plate, etc. as there are certainly some weak spots.

description.text:
Got stuff floating around in your drawers that needs to be tided up? Look no further.

OpenSCAD remake of Glaedi's IKEA ALEX Boxes, which are great, but difficult to customize and missing a few sizes I wanted. Every aspect of this design, including the corner radius and wall thickness, can be customized to make the best use of your space.

Sizing details:

The 1x1 box is 6cm square on the outside edge (minus a 0.5mm on every edge to account for some error in printing and ensure it's a loose fit). Other boxes are similar -- the 2x3 box, for instance, is 12cm x 18cm minus 0.5mm on all edges.

This is my first thing, so bear with me if I've done the Customizer settings wrong on the first pass.

There should be no need for any sort of rafts or support.

I have several mirrors and 2 pieces of glass that I use for my printers. It's a bit of a pain finding somewhere to easily store them so I've created this stand so that they're easily accessible. There are 4 slots for 4mm beds and 4 slots for 5mm.

The dimensions of the stand are:
150mm long x 52mm wide x 50mm high

There was also a lot of blank real estate on the sides, so I threw in a dragon, because everything is cooler with dragons. I've uploaded both versions so if you're a dragon hater you can use that one and be lame ;)

Update...already
So I quickly realized that the balance would be off and it would tip over, so I've added storage trays to both sides to keep it balanced.

Update #2
So after printing out the test piece, the slots weren't wide enough for my bed surfaces. I've extended them each by 1mm so 4 of them are now 4mm wide and 4 are 5mm wide. Depending on the tolerances of your printer you may get better spacing than me.

title: Leki Ski/Hiking Pole Fixture for Backpack

description.text:
These caps serve to protect the tips of skiing or hiking poles, while at the same time providing a means to fix them securely to your backpack. The usual loops found on some backpacks may be too small or inconveniently placed for some poles, which is why I came up with this idea for a better fixture.

I have designed the caps for Leki Aergon III poles (http://amzn.to/2Ee72df), but they should fit most other pole tips as well.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

You may need to rotate the 3D model first to stand on its base depending on your slicer.

2 printed copies of the model will be required for a pair of hiking poles.

Printed in PLA. I designed the holes as squares with a diameter of 4.5mm instead of circles to avoid bridging issues and the need for support.

Assembly

Tie a pair of printed caps together with a short piece of shoe lace or a thin accessory cord (3-4mm in diameter).

Attach the tied together pair to the pole loop on your backpack with a cow hitch to prevent it from falling off when not in use.

I hope that you will find this useful!

title: Overwatch Backlit Logo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Overwatch logo that is backlit by WS2812B Addressable LEDs and can be hung with a screw to the wall. Designed to be printed on the 300x300 bed of the CR10, idk if scalling it up for the S5 or anything larger that the regular CR-10 will allow the parts to snap together so try at your own risk! Parts snap together, no screws or glue to assemble the parts. Parts have .3mm gap to give a snug fit. I noticed that the actual logo includes a chamfer. So I included both the flat(the one in the picture) and the chamfered version(I haven't printed it yet. It shouldn't need supports for the lip but your printer may vary.). I soldered the LEDs with a sight arch to contour with the logo. For the upper Arch, I soldered 3 LEDs together and made a mirror set glued 2 of them back to back (that's hard to explain) see the picture. Glue the LED upside down for a brighter shine. Regular 5050 RGB strips can be used if you don't want to mess with coding or don't know your way around WS2812B LEDs. But I encourage you learn! These LEDs allow animations like the one in the video. It adds a more cool factor. lol. I bought the controller and LEDs from Amazon. You'll need exactly 60LEDs. Check the Print section to see what settings I used to print.

You'll need:
~300g of Black for the Main face of the logo
~300g of Clear/translucent white for the rest
WS2812B 60LEDs (1Meter): http://a.co/bF08lyQ
WS2812B 300LED (5Meters) **recommended if you acidentally burn a pixel...I might have done that...:http://a.co/dObqxoc
WS2812B RGB Controller: http://a.co/ekcMmpP
5V 4A power supply (Logo will consume 3.6A MAX but better safe than sorry): http://a.co/inRU0Eu
Of course the usual DIY tools like soldering iron(recommend the SainSmart Pro32), solder, wire, sire stripper,etc.

When you print and make this, I'd LOVE to see pictures of it! Upload them here or tag me on instagram @michaeltranster
Tipping is a thing too ;)

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Notes:

**I printed the bottom base in a really clear PLA and the top Arch insert in a natural milky PLA to help defuse the light more.
Print all parts in the orientation that they are when imported. (flat side down)
All was printed with a .4 nozzle at .3 layer height.
Print the clear pieces with about 5 walls so when the LED shine through it, you don't see infill.
Print the black with what ever infill and perimeters you'd like, It doesn't matter. (Recommend 2 walls and 15-20% infill.

NO SUPPORTS NEEDED FOR ANY PART.

title: Starman
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So I think the world was inspired recently by the launch of SpaceX's Falcon Heavy! I know I sure was. I thought I'd model Starman to remember the occasion.

I scaled some things up to make it a little easier to print. I'm more than happy for anyone to share a remix of further sliced parts. This is about as far as I can go at the moment. My brain is kind of fried from looking at all of the details on this.

Apologies to anyone expecting higher detail, this is slightly cartoonish. I just wanted it to be printable by most, rather than photorealistic.

I included a version of Starman unposed in case anyone wanted to try printing him in some ninjaflex or something! Not sure how that will turn out, but I figured it was a decent option!

If anyone has any suggestions to improve this, let me know!

A special thanks to my supporters and Patrons! Without all of your encouragement things like this wouldn't exist!

-Steve

UPDATE 2/11/2018: So I uploaded a version of the roadster with the steering wheel and the seats taken out. I've also included the removed seats with starman mounted to one of them. I'm test printing them now, and I'll upload some shots of it tomorrow. Cheers.

UPDATE 2/15/2018: I uploaded another version of the base with the hardmode camera mounts sliced off. I laid them down on their optimal side for printing, and to allow support in an inconspicuous spot on the backside of the model.

I also re-uploaded the regular hardmode version, removing 3 floating artifacts that were left internally.

I've removed the work-in-progress flag. Everything should be printable at this point. If you do find any other errors, let me know!

remixed_from.title: D20 Cat Treat Toy - fixed and rotated

title: D20 Cat Treat Toy with Expanded Treat Opening

description.text:
My cats were having difficulty getting their treats out of the original D20, even after scraping away some of the material with a knife, so my completely unskilled self brought the original into TinkerCad, sized it up by 20%, and expanded the hole. Consider it an easy mode for your less intelligent cats (or an alternative for bigger treats).

Sorry if it looks messy - I'm new to this and had to eyeball the expansion.

One thing - it seems I overshot the size a bit. I originally had resized it to fit Temptations treats, but the hole is quite wide for even those - they fall out pretty readily and without a ton of effort by the cat. You might want to size it back down a bit (maybe 20%?) to get the hole a bit smaller unless you want to go super easy on your cats or you've got a bigger treat in mind.

Still, I figured I'd keep this model up as an alternative for people who would rather print a smaller D20 with a bigger hole than scale the whole thing up.

title: monoprice select / wanhao i3 fixed bed calibration

description.text: I really don't like the springs that this printer comes with, doesn't seem stable and my machine was always going out of calibration. There are caps on thingiverse that are supposed to make them more stable but they still lean. So what I did was got some 4-40 screws (I know this comes with metric but american thread is easier to acquire in the states), and mounted them the same way as the existing ones (screw down, nut underneath). Now press some 4-40 nuts into this knockoff (which are larger than the original metal ones with nice chunky knurl), thread that on (making sure the nut is facing up), then thread one more nut under the bottom metal bed. Start the bed low, zero the machine out.. then slowly creep the bottom nut up, re-tightening the knockoff down. Not close enough? loosen the knockoff, give the bottom nut a turn, re-tighten. Ideally if you printed 8 of these, it might make it easier to turn the bottom nut.

title: Snapping Hinged Infinity Cube, Magic Cube, Flexible Cube, Folding Cube

description.text:
Snapping Hinged Infinity Cube, Magic Cube, Flexible Cube, Folding Cube

Update: posted 25mm^3 version.

{My students and I so love the infinity cube. I decided to make a hinged one for more flexibility. It is not easy but is fun!}

The magic/flexible/folding/infinity cube (or whatever fancy name you could think of) is easy to build using wooden or cardboard cubes. In my case, I first made a huge model using 48 polydron squares and adhesive tape, just to track the symmetries of the structure. It is an appealing challenge to do it in a 3D design world. In this project, I took advantage of previous work with snapping joints. The result goes beyond my expectations.

It is a bit frustrating to assemble in the beginning, as a puzzle should be. Once you get the symmetry worked out, you won’t be disappointed! Also, you could try printing in various colors and then mix and match them for an infinity cube, to further explore the symmetry of the structure.

Each cube is 36mm x 36mm x36mm.

There are two versions—the regular version with rounded joints and a loose version that allows more room to maneuver. Both versions came out well on my Flashforge Creator Pro. Please try the halves if your printer bed is not big enough.

For my Flexible TPU model, please refer to https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2786094 .

References

  1. https://www.math.nmsu.edu/~breakingaway/Lessons/MFC/MFC.html
  2. https://www.chicaandjo.com/2008/05/08/magic-folding-wooden-photo-cubes/

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 to .2mm

Infill:

5-20%

Notes:

The regular version might need a bit of support for smooth rounded joints at the bottom of the print However, it worked well for me without support.

Please use a higher infill (40%, for example) for the connectors.

Be patient. Clean up the prints if necessary. Try to make sense of the symmetry of this thing, using the attached figures. Then, snap the 16 connectors to make a flexible cube -- taking it to infinity!

title: MakerGear M2 Dial Indicator Slider V2

description.text:
This dial indicator slider is built on top of a phone clamp that allows a quick way to setup dial indicator without messing with the hotend.

You'll need:

  1. Phone clamp: https://goo.gl/dVhf8b
  2. PTFE mouse dics: https://goo.gl/PzNsJC
  3. 1/4" -20 thread: https://goo.gl/p892Vn

My measurement was a little off on the dial indicator mount (for Turlen brand, but it fits) and height of the bracket was too low to clear the screw nuts on the underside of X axis frame. So I just epoxied another set of brackets on top of them. STP files are included, feel free to improve it.

The bracket with PTFE must be a perfect fit to the thickness of X axis frame. My M2 is the first generation from 2013. Measure twice and print once.

Assemble Instruction:
Print four pieces of sliders and the dial indicator mount. Screw the mount to the phone clamp with 1/4"-20 screw and epoxy the brackets as shown in the picture. Finally apply PTFE on all three interior walls of slider.

Installation Instruction:
Move the print head to the far right and attach the clamp on X axis frame.

title: Strong Ash Fridge Magnets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's my design for fridge Magnets. I sized it for 1.25"x0.25" Neodymium Magnets. My fridge has Stainless Steel panels on the front. They are less ferromagnetic than the old style enamel coated steel fridges, but there is still some iron in there. The trick is that you need some pretty strong magnets to make use of it. I liked the aspect ratio of large flat magnets, so that's what i picked fro this project. I searced around a bit and these guys are the same price on either eBay or Amazon, so I ordered from Amazon. $13 for 10, so $1.30 each. Not bad.

I made a few different head shapes for the magnet. I ended up liking the "small head" version the best, although my wife and daughter like the "loop" version the best.

I have also included a version that just encapsulates the magnet, so you can load it and any other STL you want into your slicer and print it as a single piece. For example, you can see in my photos that I tried adding a rose, but the rose didn't print well. I'll try again, but I just wanted to upload these so y'all can try them out :)

Process (for printers running Marlin or a derivative):

  1. Slice the STL in your slicer of choice.
  2. After slicing, view the sliced file layer by layer.
  3. Find the layer that is the first one that forms the ceiling around the magnet
  4. Open the sliced gcode file in a text editor and insert an M600 command immediately before the start of the layer that forms the ceiling above the magnet.
  5. When the print gets to the M600, it will pause and pull away from the print.
  6. Add magnet. I use a paper towel to clean the top of the magnet with acetone or IPA to help the filament to stick better.
  7. Resume print. The first layer over the magnet may look very bad, but just let it go and monitor it. The next layer will probably smooth it out and everything will be fine :)

CAUTION: Neodymium magnets can be very dangerous. I assume no responsibility for your handling of the magnets. I tried to print a few of these next to each other on the bed and the magnets kept interacting and leaping out of position. One magnet shattered into very sharp shards.

DOUBLE CAUTION: Do not let your child swallow these magnets. That would be like the end of the world. Even the fully printed and encapsulated magnets are technically too small to let a sub 3yr old play with, although they are hopefully too large to be swallowed.

These are the magnets that fit perfectly: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MSTKTSF/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

author: tprchuck

description.text:
Do you have a 3M tape machine?
These machines are pretty common in factories taping the box closed before it gets stacked onto a pallet.

This little finger will bolt into the square aluminum plate that is right before the applying roller in a 3M accuglide tape head.,.

This won't do much for you on the upper head, but on the lower head, it makes a huge difference. Bolt this finger to the plate from the back side, so the shark fin pokes through the slot. You'll need a tiny nut and flat head screw, like 2mm or 3mm. This gives the tape a convex shape so it will hold itself up and it won't fall over.

Also, the 2 metal tabs with the slot in them, bend those down, towards the tape. The adhesive side of the tape is up right there and if those tabs are bent out, then there is too much surface area for the adhesive to grab on to. By bending the tabs down, just the tips of the tabs come into contact with the adhesive and help hold the tape down in the convex shape with minimal adhesive contact.

While I'm at it I'll tell you to lubricate the felt pad that covers the blade, once a week or so, with a light weight oil like 3 in 1 oil. This keeps the blade lubricated and helps minimize tape build up on the blade.

Send me a message if you want a 3M tape head maintenance and adjustment training class. It's what I do. Its one of the things I do.

There are 4 fingers on a common brim for easy printing. Cut apart post print.
I printed these in ABS and in PETG, both at 100% infill for strength.
This is a 1:1 scale model of a flash drive I have without the case. I would enjoy seeing some one printing this on a fine detail printer without scaling it up!

author: mccourtau

description.text:
Others have made them, and I have printed them... and the ones I have printed have always broken, in the middle of a print.

I think this design will have better success as it eliminates the failure points all the others I have used had. It uses actual metal nuts in the provided openings that can be placed after printing, and either 3 or 4mm set screws. I also provided couplers that accept either 2 or 4 nuts.

As always I have included source files for easy customization in the form of STEP (.stp) files. STEP files can be opened in a variety of different CAD packages, such as AutoDesk's FREE to use Fusion 360.

Print ON!!!!

The ID's have been slightly oversized because my printer tends to print ID's a bit small. This is intended to be used with a 5mm stepper motor's drive shaft and an 8mm lead screw. The actual ID's of the design file are 5.3mm and 8.3mm respectively.

As long as your printing one, print two. That way if one fails, you have a spare to print more of these couplers!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Silver

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print, slip some nuts in, align the nuts with the holes and begin threading in a set screw. Couple your motor's 5mm drive shaft to your 8mm lead screw and snug up the bolts.

Most aluminum couplers come with either 3mm or 4mm set screws. I had both, so I conveniently made designs for both.

Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: bardiir
remixed_from.title: Tortoise at the bottom of everything with flat bottom for easier printing

description.text:
Remix from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2386601

I wanted to experiment with using 3d printed molds to cast concrete sculptures so I took the tortoise from above and make it into a mold. It worked well in the end, but melting the PLA off from around the concrete was a major pain. This process is destructive to the mold. Perhaps printing in a flexible material would be better, but it didn't turn out too bad for experimentation.

Slow and careful melting of the PLA with a blowtorch and pulling the plastic off with pliers worked to free the concrete.

NOTE some support is required because there are some overhangs. I was able to carefully pull the supports out with long needle nose pliers. The neck/head hole was the hardest part to clean.

The Tarka MBT codenamed "Tegu" by Solforce's Black Section is an early tank design from the Ks'Sartha Ullaru Design bureau. It aligns with general Tarka combat philosophy by sacrificing armour in exchange for cross country speed and maneuverability. The Tegu is very fast for a tracked MBT by Solforce standards, but is prone to breakdowns and turbine fires. The main gun is a very solid, if uninspired, Mass Driver design that has served the Tarka Military for over a century.

Find out more about Ground Pounders and the ground forces of other Sword of the Stars races here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/267730/Ground_Pounders/

The Large Zorcher from Chex Quest!

Chex Quest was a mod of the '90s video game Doom, which was given out for free in boxes of Chex cereal. Instead of guns, you would use a "Zorcher" to keep slime monsters from getting your cereal soggy. It was a...weird time for video games.

Anyways, I'm a huge fan of Doom and retro video games in general, so I figured I'd take a crack at modeling some of the Zorchers from the game!

This is the 'Large Zorcher', which acts like the shotgun from Doom. This model has a removable ammo clip, which uses four 1/4" X 1/16" magnets to hold it in place.

This model has been designed to print out in three colors, so just print everything out and put it together!

author: hallucination

description.text:
My wife is a science teacher who teaches teachers how to teach science. While preparing a biology lesson for elementary teachers (see photo) she realized that she had misplaced the cap of her bottle. Being resourceful she simply covered it with plastic wrap and a rubber band.

But I have a 3D printer! So I downloaded CreativeTool's most excellent bottle cap and printed one out for her. Problem solved.

She was so impressed that she asked me to print another one and drill a hole in it to act as a drain. (see bottom cap in picture)

But I have a 3D printer! So I simply uploaded the cap into Tinkercad, booleaned a hole into it, and printed one out for her. Problem solved. That's what you have here.

This really impressed her.

So me asked me if I could print 20 sets for her students.

Well, I do have a 3D printer…

title: Star Wars - Dark Holocron BASE
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I don't know whether I got weird/funky tea lights, or if the design standard has just changed, but the tea lights I have ended up being too tall for this to work properly, and wound up creating a dark line across the bottom of the holocron panels, hiding a good chunk of the symbols.

That simply wouldn't do.

So I created this base that will securely hold a tea light, and keep its lip flush with the bottom of the inside of the Holocron. This way, the light spreads out evenly and no detail is lost. It's keyed to the tea light holder already present in the design, so it fits snugly in one direction and one direction only. YOUR PRINTER MUST HAVE GOOD TOLERANCES FOR THE TWO PIECES TO FIT TOGETHER PROPERLY.

print_settings.Notes:: I used PLA but ABS should also be safe for tropical fish. I'm not sure about marine tanks however.

description.text:
This project IS functional and actually in my aquarium right now! (see pic above)

I've been unsatisfied with my current aquarium filter and wanted a new one of my own design, however instead of an external filter that hangs off the side of the tank I wanted to make an old-school submerged filter that uses an air pump that I can stick in the corner and surround by the river rocks I use for decoration.

This piece is designed so that it can be printed on a 100x100x100mm build surface so anyone can use it.

AutoCAD files available for anyone who wants to modify and make it their own.

If you try to sell this on Shapeways or other 3D printing sites I'll drive to your house, rip your arm off, and beat you to death with it.

Printer:

Monoprice Mini & Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.8mm shells, ,2mm layer height,

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Rotate lid 90deg to print flat.

Supports only needed (according to Cura) on the funnel, however it will probably print fine without them.

I used PLA but ABS should also be safe for tropical fish. I'm not sure about marine tanks however.

Assembly

1) Place the Funnel inside the main cylinder. It will not rest on the bottom but should center itself on the tabs on the base.

2) Fill about halfway with activated charcoal (carbon).

3) Top off with some type of cloth/foam filter material.

4) Attach the lid with the two nipples inside the holes on the side of the main cylinder.

5) Insert the air intake tube (the green one in the CAD image) into a clear rubber air hose (which should be attached to an aquarium air pump).

6) Place inside your aquarium resting on the bottom; be sure to allow it to completely fill with water.

7) Turn on air pump.

Aerator/Bubble Tube

Adding a bubble tube on top of the filter would provide a decorative bubble wall that would help add oxygen to the aquarium.

Under Gravel Feet

Adding feet or a ledge to the base would stabilize the filter by partially burying it in gravel.

Lid Removal Tabs

The lid is difficult to remove. I use a blade inserted in the slots of the body right now.

Funnel Orientation Lug

A tab needs to be added to the inside of the main cylinder and a notch in the funnel to correctly align the two before attaching the lid. Right now you have to eyeball it.

description.text:
My new Anycubic I3 Mega came with a pretty good spool holder, but the printer itself barely fits on top of my lack tables, let alone with a spool next to it. I spent a while searching for a spool holder that would fit my exact model of wire shelving (they're all different dimensions, different wire diameters, etc) before I stumbled across SteelCityElectronics' solder spool holder and decided to alter the design for my own needs.

There's a stack of bearings burning a hole in my parts drawer, so I tried to integrate them into this design:
The TOP stl has a hole in the top of the table bracket, and includes a peg to fit into it and carry a 608 (skateboard/rollerblade/fidget spinner) bearing. The SIDES stl has a hole through the base of the spindle, and includes 2 pegs for 2 bearings. I haven't actually tried this method. The unlabelled stl includes both holes and prints all 3 pegs. The BASIC stl doesn't have any.

If you have a bearing handy, I recommend TOP. The spool might ride over the top of the bearing occasionally, but it seems to be doing its job for the most part. The no-bearings version is fine but I worry about the edge of the spool wearing away at the edge of the table.

  • Spindle length: 90mm
  • Spindle width (max spool internal diameter): 40mm

Printer:

Anycubic I3 Mega

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:
  • Rev1 (the black one): PLA, shrank too much when I printed it, falls off the table if you put more than 0.5Kg on it.
  • Rev2 (the one I uploaded): PETG, flexes with a full 1Kg spool but still securely holds the table.
Prints without supports. As a purely utilitarian design, I'd consider supports to be a failure.

title: bow stabilizer with hydraulic / sand damper

description.text:
I loved the stabilizer that Modified_Gemini built (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2505865), as it's a great inexpensive solution to make several length stabilizers for different tournament rules etc.. I wanted to contribute to his design. Specifically, I wanted to add a counter weight / damper on the end that could be printed. The end piece can be filled with water / liquid if your print quality will hold up to it, otherwise you can fill with sand. In theory the hydraulic effects of the water and/or sand will help combat torque while also absorbing vibrations and shock.

This stabilizer provides several parts to customize your own build. Not every part is necessary to print.

All of the parts and partial parts used to construct this are provided in the stabilizer_parts.stl file attached which can be opened for modification / customization.

Instructions below also provided by Modified_Gemini with tweaks.

Parts needed -

3 x ultralight Arrow shafts 7.2 mm (any length you desire)
5/16"x24 Bolts (A couple of printable versions are provided one of which has a v cut to allow removal if it breaks)
1 x 5/16" Flat washer

Print parts -
1 x End piece
1 x Hydraulic Stabilizer End
1 x Bolt cover (2 to choose from)
1 x Brace (or more, there are 2 to choose from)
1 x fill cap (there are two provided, one is tight and the other is a little looser)

Assembly -

Cut the arrows to identical and desired lengths and test fit in the end pieces. Slide the Braces over the arrow shafts and use a slower drying glue to ensure the pieces are aligned. Glue the brace. Slide in the 5/16" bolts, and glue the covers. The washer spacer is to allow the 5/8" flat washers to sit centered over the 5/16" bolt. Sand it down to slightly shorter than the length of the total washers. This allows the 5/15" flat washer to apply pressure on the 5/8" washers to hold them in place. Fill your end piece with your choice of sand / water or other substance for the amount you desire to achieve the effect and weight you desire. Glue the fill cap in place if using the loose cap or a liquid. If using the tight fitting cap, it can be tapped into position.

Anet A8

description.text:
These are a set of small drape molds I use to make little ceramic dishes- by smoothing a slab down over them and cutting around (to form a rim).

Clay sticks to plastic while it's wet, but, I personally have not needed a mold release with these- I simply let them sit on the molds until they're dry enough to gently pop off. This takes about 12-24 hours for me, I try to grab them right before they're leather hard. Leave them on too long and the dish will crack as the clay shrinks around the mold, so be careful. Use a mold release (one that's safe for your materials) if you'd like to work faster- or find you need it.

In the interest of speed, I don't bother optimizing print quality much. It's pretty easy to smooth any layer lines that transfer to the clay, and sometimes they're interesting enough to leave alone. These can also be used as pop-up molds (push cut slab into foam to form a dish), and I imagine they'd work well for other types of clay with the right release agents.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

5-10%

Notes:

Make it stick- if it lifts, it could severely impact its usability. I print these with the narrow "clay side" up- I feel like the tops of my prints allow for better air flow (which aids drying) than the bottom of my prints (on glass) would. You do you, though!

Printing at 100% (size-wise) will yield molds of these dimensions:
Small Flower: 3.5" petal-petal across wider side, 2" petal-petal across narrow side
Larger Flower: 5" petal-petal across wider side, 3.5" petal-petal across narrow side

Small Hexagon: 3.5" point-point across wider side, 2.5" point-point across narrow side
Larger Hexagon: 4.5" point-point across wider side, 3.5" point-point across narrow side

Small Octagon: 3.5" point-point across wider side, 2" point-point across narrow side
Larger Hexagon: 5" point-point across wider side, 3.5" point-point across narrow side

They're all .75" high.

A couple of clips I printed for keeping some electrical cords out of the way.

print_settings.Notes:: This is sized to be printed in PETG. The clip fits snugly on the shaft, and the accessory clip holds the accessory comfortably without too much play but is still easy to slide the accessory in and out of. If you're printing in PLA, ABS, or something else with more shrinkage than PETG you may need to scale it up to accommodate the extra shrinking. The "DysonClipTest.stl" model is a 4mm thick cross-section that I used to tweak the sizes when I was designing this part, so you can use that to dial in your scaling factor.

description.text:
Clip to bring one of the Dyson V7 Motorhead stick vacuum's attachments along with you while vacuuming.

There's a lot to like about Dyson's new stick vacuums, but when you take the extension tube off the motor, the vacuum's gaping maw doesn't have the pull required for detail work...and since there's no way to bring the crevice attachment with you short of sticking it in your pocket while you're on the go, you've got to remember to come back around for a second pass to get all the little bits that escaped the floor head.

The attachments all clip in and out of the vacuum, the extension tube, and the accessory holder on the charging dock, so there's no reason not to have a clip to keep one on the vacuum's extension tube to take it with you.

title: DIY heated bed, thoughts and theory
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A recent project with high temp resistance wires has left me with an idea. Fortunate because I'm also working on a new printer which, because of its increased bed size, will also be needing a new heater pad. The picture is a sneak peek of a project I'll be releasing here in a month or so.

This leads us into the world of joule heating. Using some basic ohm's law, empirical resistance measurements (I'll save you the calculus) and a touch of insulation, we should be able to make our own heated beds. Note that so far this is, at best, considered 'reliable theory'. The principles of joule heating are well documented. Like any good engineering task, the goal isn't to come up with something new, but instead to reuse foundations to build upon.

Update: I suppose I should explain the calculus bit. Normally, when calculating resistance per volume, you're given a number measured in ohm/m. This is a measure of the resistance of a one meter cubed chunk of the material in question with two plates opposite each other. Rather than go through that math, use the quoted 'ohm/ft' measurement often listed under the purchase page of the wire you're looking at.

I digress, let's get into the meat of the thought. We only need the most bearbone math skills here and the work of great physicists before us. They lay under the ground while we stand upon their shoulders.

Ohm's law can be stated mathmatically in the form I=V/R, where V is voltage across a resistor, R is the resistance (opposition to electron flow) and I is the resulting current that will flow measured in amps. This will be handy in one moment.

This all comes into play when designing the heater element. We calculate power, measured in watts (joules/sec), using the simplified formula P=VI. Simple right? Well, it's not very well useable in that form to us. How much resistance do we need? How many volts are we putting across this element?

Say we have 12 volts to use and we want a 200 watt heater element. That is to say, we want 200 watts or 200 joules per second to disipate as heat from the element. We can ascertain how much current (I) we need to flow through the element by dividing our 200 watt requirement by our 12 volts and that gets us about 16 amps. Now that Ohm's law we looked at before comes into play. We can transpose the I=V/R form into the R=V/I to find the resistance that at 12v will allow 16 amps to flow through it. In this case, we get 0.75 Ohms.

As for the making of the element, we have to select a wire that both withstands a high temp and has a low enough resistance per length required. Kanthal and nichrome are two that come to mind immediatly. Certain Kanthal alloys have iron in them, while nichrome is mostly nickel with a bit of chromium. For this purpose I would choose the nichrome 80 alloy at 20 AWG. This wire has a resistance per foot of 0.6348 ohms.

When 2 one foot lengths of this wire are placed in parallel, you can use twice the length of wire to get the same resistance. To electrically isolate the wires from the bed you can use a large sheet of thermal silicone, typically used for MOSFETs and CPUs.
A bit of thin ceramic wool and a wrapper made of aluminum duct tape and kapton tape, one to insulate the other to conduct, will work to keep the heat direct upwards towards the metal. Don't forget your choice of thermistor in the package.

Double check the element for shorts after all is wrapped and attach some 12-14 AWG copper wire to the nichrome.

@Arcmatt has led me to this thing: www.thingiverse.com/thing:52537
This project and the link in it are exactly what I'm talking about. Congrats go out to the creator of the jig and the subsequent write up on it. Looks like a beauty. Note that our write ups on the subject are independent of one another; here I toss out theory, there he tosses out reality.

I would **highly** advise double and triple checking the math, voltages and electrical isolation before applying power to any sort of homemade electronic circuitry. For this type of element, as with other heated beds, polarity is non-specific.

description.text:
I made some classroom manipulative to help my students who struggle with understanding how to balance ions.

If you a teacher who needs one more way to demonstrate this skill, a parent with a child who needs extra help on this section or a student yourself and you need to better understand how to balance ions, then this is for you!

MakerBot

MakerBot Replicator 2

No

Supports:

No

5%

Notes:

Once printed I used a sharpie to colour the top surface black to make it stand out better, if you had the time and ULTIMATE will power you could change filament to a contrasting colour for the top 3-4 layers.
NGSS CCSS

This is a manipulative to help students learn what can be an abstract concept of balancing ions in a concrete manner. Using these blocks there is no way the student can not find the correct number of ions to balance the compound.
Use as part of an activity, I would create a worksheet that uses the ions in this kit to help them practice, once they have done it a couple times students usually get the hang of it.
Just the ions and perhaps a table / worksheet for them to complete using the blocks.

• Ions
  • ion
  • Balancing ions
20min
Just print the blocks and prepare a worksheet.

Density: 80%
Print speed: 40 or 50

Printing time Approx: 1h 23m

author: aishwaryau

description.text:
Tape your iPhone headphone controller to the carrier, adjust the carrier position with the knurled nut so the cam just hits the + button, set the turntable on top, aim your iPhone at the subject you place in the center and turn the crank. One complete rotation of the turntable equals 30 exposures- I use the free version of 3df Zephyr to build a 3d model from these.

I'm just starting out 3d scanning with photogrammetry, and I really, really wanted to like the $30 3D scanner (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1762299). Unfortunately, it has some problems, and after trying to fix one after another I decided to scrap it and start from scratch with my own design.

The turntable's weight is supported by four rollers, and the drive is by worm gear, so no more skipping teeth or rocking with lightweight subjects. The iPhone headphone control holder is easily exposed and has an adjustment nut, so you can fine-tune the cam pressure without tearing the whole thing down or making a bunch of shims. I didn't include an iPhone stand, since there's no shortage of excellent designs already out there. According to S3D, using $25/kg filament the whole thing cost $3.47 to print.

Update 2/11/2018: Just added one piece turntable and frame STLs for folks with large printers. For folks printing the two-piece versions, my dovetails are friction fit and shouldn't require glue, but they're directional- make certain you're snapping the small part down on the large part, not the other way around.

Update 2/22/2018: Per request, just added turntable and frame versions to allow printing on very small printers (110mm diameter). For the frame, print TinyFrameA, two of the existing FrameB, and one each TinyFrameC and TinyFrameD. For the turntable, print TinyTurntableA and six TinyTurntableB. As always, place the male dovetail over the female and press together, not the other way around.

Printer:

QIDI Tech 1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.02

Infill:

20%

And then when I try to assemble the shaft to the worm, it acts like the shaft is too big, and the worm's hole is too small. I've tried heating the plastic with a lighter to let the shaft "melt" into the worm's threads, but then it doesn't stay, so I used a hot glue gun which temporarily helped until the turntable is pushed all the way down on the frame, at which the turntable sticks. I'm thinking I'm going to have to edit this print, and instead of threads, make it a square joint, much like you did with the cam on the shaft.

comments.text: I assume the worm is falling over before the print is complete? For skinny prints with small footprints, sometimes it's helpful to use a raft, or even supports (not necessary to hold up the layers, just to enlarge the footprint and give it a more stable base while printing).
comments.author: PowerScissor

comments.text: Yeah, I had the 1st attempt fall over, then I've tried with a raft several times also.  It's just the fact that the worm gear itself has the overhangs which even with good even cooling curl up ever so slightly.  Generally with a solid part the nozzle's heat will just push it back down with the next layer....but because it's so tall and thin...the "tower" tends to bend back and forth instead and I end up with slightly misshapen worm gear that just won't work.  I might give it a few more tries the next time I switch filament to something that doesn't curl up as much with the overhangs....or an external fan to help with even more air-flow.  I haven't given up yet. :)  And I've scaled everything down a little to fit on my print bed...so I'm sure I would be having better luck with 100% scale.  Had I printed the worm first instead of last...I probably would have chosen to use your 2 piece models instead of scaling down.

author: Lucifor

description.text: BeeBee-66 Lite camera mount 10°/20°

title: 200 Watt Bluetooth 5 Speaker Boombox *Source Files Included!*

description.text:
So I got bored again.

This project involves some serious electricity. Both in amps and volts. There is 120v AC inside this completed unit and many many amps of lithium-ion power otherwise. There will be detailed wiring guides included and in the end it's no harder to wire than you're average 3D printer. Take care, use your head and take your time. Don't substitute wire gauges!

This time I got on ebay and bought some stuff from China. I will be including the links to the exact items I bought. Feel free to substitute! Some from Amazon, some form Ebay, some from McMaster-Carr.

The idea was a mostly portable 200 watt bluetooth speaker. I wanted lithium ion power and as many watts as China says I can have.

I have used the TPA3116 amps before and they work great. I found this one https://goo.gl/2eBmeX on Ebay pretty cheap. It has decent heat sink, good selection of adjustments, good input and output connector options and even a 5v output plus it runs on 12-24 volts

I went looking for a bluetooth module with decent connectors and features that's not obnoxious. I found https://goo.gl/LzuAqu on ebay again. This one is bluetooth 4.0 with a set of wires and JST type connectors which I have the crimps for. It's 7-30 volt power so very easy to use. It has solder tabs for buttons and isn't crazy big or small. It even has microphone connection for phone use, I;m gonna use that too.

I wanted a battery gauge so I grabbed https://goo.gl/yxdiJG off ebay. It's simple to use and mount so yeah, all I needed.

On to speakers! I got https://goo.gl/xga3TQ for side speakers and one https://goo.gl/k5LkNR off ebay for the sub. They are cheap car speakers but certainly decent enough for this job. Plus look, so yellow aven if they are a pyle..

Needed some buttons for the bluetooth and went with 16mm stainless steel flush mounts off ebay. I didnt want to wait so paid a bit more to get them from the USA. https://goo.gl/n4Y2GZ

Now on to the batteries. I used to repair tools and have a lot of "bad" lithium batteries for drills and things. I tore them apart carefully and extracted the cells. Using all the chargers I could find and my load testers I managed to get 18 good 18650 cells. With that number I am doing 6 packs of 3 parallel cells. If you go for used batteries TEST THEM FOR CAPACITY and always use a balance board.

There are other ways to get the cells too. One of the cheapest is to find power banks on amazon with decent ratings. One I like for cells and the board inside is handy too is https://goo.gl/EmR9rU This thing hovers around $25 most of the time though for a full load here you would need 3 of them.

So this runs at 24 ish volts. That's 6 x 18650's together in series hence my pack of 3 batteries in parallel and 6 of those packs in series for 3x the amps and 6x the volts of a single cell.

Now for some wiring of this pack!

I made another CrapCAD diagram for this one:

This shows the 6 packs of 3 18650's wired together in series/parallel. The protection board monitors packs so it has the same 7 connections the charger does. You need to Y these to run a set to the charger.

I used this protection board for 6 cells: https://goo.gl/dor51J

I used https://goo.gl/5hYXWg for the set of balance wires run to the charger and just split them at the board.

To charge it I plan to use a nice hobby charger. I picked https://goo.gl/8H27Vi for t's size and price, plus a nice display! Going to mount this in the top left side with the wheel and screen accessible and all the wiring connections made inside per the diagram above. With this balance charger and the protection board inside the unit should have good battery life and safe charging.

I will post wiring, pictures and better instructions once I finish this. For now this is just kinda a way to keep track of it for me and you.

So to get power into this I am using an IEC plug from Amazon. It has a switch and noise suppression. https://goo.gl/Z5rbQ2 and it's cheap.

Then I wanted a way to power the unit from the wall while it charges. To do this I got a 6amp 24v power supply from amazon https://goo.gl/PUX2F2 and a 120 volt double throw relay https://goo.gl/VuYzsV The relay connects the power into the amp from the battery when no 120v is applied over to the power supply one it gets 120v power so nothing gets shorted together. Also the input plug has a fuse.

To wire the relay, charger, 24v power supply and AC side see this diagram:

The blue wires are AC 120v. Red is positive 24 volts DC and black is negative 24 volts DC.

With this arrangement the unit will switch from battery to wall power as soon as the AC is turned on. The relay prevents the battery and 24 volt DC power supply from connecting together directly and causing potential issues, like a fire. Besides powering the load which is the amplifier board the 24 volt DC power supply also powers the charger to charge the internal batteries.

Now I designed this to fit on my Anet A8. The box is meant to be screwed and glued together. I ordered https://www.mcmaster.com/#99397a489/=1bi6neq from Mcmaster-Carr. These are meant to be used in plastics, stainless steel and look pretty good.They wont vibrate out either but on the main body I plan to superglue the flat edges too.

It currently uses 145 screws >.> Yeah, I like the look of them though.

Thank you, enjoy, like, share and comment! Don't be shy!

  • Updated 2/10/2018 with latest files and AMF copies.

  • Update 2/18/2018 Printing parts! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YOHUB8JxVU8

  • Update 2/21/2018 Split up the HUGE rear sections into panels to make it easier to print. Print one of each file. You'll need a lot of screws to put it together. I recommend using PETG. I have the fronts and amp enclosure printed in glow in the dark PLA and am printing the sides in semi-clear green PETG. Assembly to come.

BOM:

  • https://goo.gl/f8juVY Amplifier X 1
  • https://goo.gl/iwatZN Bluetooth X 1
  • https://goo.gl/s8uHDS Battery Meter X 1
  • https://goo.gl/nTYHZR Stereo Speakers X 1 pair
  • https://goo.gl/r8pY65 6.5" Subwoofer X1
  • https://goo.gl/h2M2rf Buttons x 4 [I ordered 5 because it's cheap]
  • https://goo.gl/oKeJLv Balance Board X 1
  • https://goo.gl/Kh2d17 Charger X 1
  • https://goo.gl/T63a3w Input Panel X 1
  • https://goo.gl/hkNt4R 24V Power Supply X 1
  • https://goo.gl/o31v9s 120V SPDT Relay X 1
  • https://goo.gl/TNwmzV Screws X 150
  • https://goo.gl/sL1DXT Source of batteries, it is meant to use 18 x 18650s but can use as few as 6, or 12.

Thank you Thingiverse community for inspiring me to make this junk! Like, enjoy and share!

  • Update 2-21-2018 Added wiring diagrams and instructions. Last of the parts ordered.

  • Update 2-23-2018 Added the place for the IDST charger and built retention straps for it.

  • Update 3-7-2018 Finished the final touches and uploaded the Solidworks source files for easy customization..

Have fun!

description.text:
This is GADGET, the robotic GREMLIN.
Since I first saw the Gremlins movie in 1984, I've wanted a Gremlin.
The problem is, they are mythical creatures. It came down to 3 "C"s...

  • Capture (chances of success 0.0005%) How many Yetis, Leprechauns & Fairies are caught?
  • Conjure (chances of success 10%) Lifetime study of Dark arts & unsavoury sacrifices required...
  • Create (chances of success 75%) Design, 3D print, assemble and program

I chose the Create option ( even though computers and I don't get along)
Thanks to the EZ-B v4 from EZ- ROBOTS, I believe I can bring my creation to life.
My hopes are that he will be joystick controlled, and eventually be an A.I. autonomous companion.

The ezrobot camera has 640x480 resolution at 20fps with no latency. It is capable of color tracking, objection recognition, facial recognition and more.

The ez-bv4 boasts 200MHz of 32-bit processing (ARM Cortex-M3 & Microchip PIC32), 5 volt tolerant I/O, energy efficient digital switching power supply, Wi-Fi connectivity with security, embedded web server, amplified digital audio with speaker, 3 I²C ports, 3 x UARTs, 24 multi-use servo/digital/serial ports, 73 servos (Dynamixel & PWM), 8 analog ports, and integrated video.

Ultra sonic sensor lets him "see" obstacles up to 6ft away.
Additional parts required for this project are:
*1 EZ-B v4.2 developer kit (contents: 1 ezbv4, plug in bracket, camera, ultrasonic sensor, 4 HDD servos, 2 continous servos, servo extension cables, battery pack...)

  • 4 more HDD servos
  • 4 micro HDD servos
  • 1 tower pro sg90 servo (for jaw)
  • camera extension cable
  • 10 more servo extension cables (for arms)
  • 12 x drywall screws 1" (8 to assemble torso & 4 to attach stabilizers)
  • 6 bearings (608, for inline feet support and stabilizers)
  • several tubes of crazy glue (Gel is highly recommended)
  • unbelieveable amount of patience

Special Thanks to:
3D modeller Hoinz for the original model @ https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:258879
and to fellow Pinshaper richard swika, whose comment on my Krampus project pointed me towards the EZ-ROBOT system and made all this possible.

Special notes :

  • you must 3D print 2 of the wheel models & glue on a rubber band strip, DO NOT STRETCH the rubber band while gluing in place, you want the rubber to be "spongey" for best traction
  • use servo horns provided with servos (shoulders, elbows, upper biceps...)
  • videos
    first sign of life, head and jaw, joystick controlled @ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=alnPy5QHD4Y&list=PLyihtXhIBu9PD7JindfB_JMCtx-NZL8iq&index=7
    servo test @ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CduttaEIQVY&list=PLyihtXhIBu9PD7JindfB_JMCtx-NZL8iq&index=8
    Assembly video @ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EXWklJNU-Dc&list=PLyihtXhIBu9PD7JindfB_JMCtx-NZL8iq&index=9&t=1s

title: GoPro Hero 5 Session Adapter for the Feiyu-Tech WG Lite 1-Axis Gimbal

description.text:
Update v2:
Strengthened the side walls by 0.75mm and widened the cutout for the on/off button as well as the cutouts on the side for easier sd card access.

==================

This adapter will allow the usage of the GoPro Hero 5 Session camera on the Feiyu-Tech WG Lite 1-axis gimbal. I did a lot of research finding an official adapter, but it seems there is none.

This adapter is designed to be printed with stiff material (PLA or similar). The baseplate (the part replacing the original camera mount on the gimbal) is designed to be printed upside-down, so the offstands on the back have the most possible precision there can be.

The camera sleeve is glued to the baseplate to assemble both parts. There is no guidance standoff to align both parts by intent to make sure, both the baseplate and the sleeve offer the most plane surface to help the glue stick really good, so bear that in mind when glueing the things together (an alignment aid would cause support material to be printed on either of the two glueing sufcaces).

Supports:

No

Notes:

It's better to crank up the perimeters and top/bottom layers to strengthen your print rather than to raise the infill percentage.

On my print I used 4 perimeter shells as well as 7 top & bottom layers on a 0.1mm layer height.

description.text:
This is a fan mount that attaches onto the RepRapPro Ormerod to cool across the heatbed.
  • Direction is fully adjustable.
  • Uses one 40mm/50mm/60mm fan.
    • Please feel free to edit my design! It's always interesting to see how people can develop others work!

I printed mine with my RepRapPro Ormerod.
  • First, print out parts 1, 2 and 3. Choose your desired part 3 according to your fan size. (The photos show the 50mm fan version)
  • Use one M4 nut inside part 2 and use an M4 bolt to attach part 1 to part 2.
  • Use one M3 nut and bolt to attach part 2 to part 3.
  • Use two M3 nuts and bolts to attach the fan onto part 3.
  • Attach it onto the X Axis of the Ormerod (see photos).
  • Wires run along the X Axis the same as the extruder wires.

author: XDr4g0nX

title: The face puzzle of Ellis Island

description.text:
This puzzle looks very easy, right? It would take just a couple of seconds to figure out that it's a human head and to put all the pieces in the right place...

Now imagine that you are an immigrant from the old world in the early 20 th century. After a horrible and long trip over the sea, most often in poor conditions, you arrive at Ellis island hoping to begin a new life, you are starving, sleep-deprived, even ill, in a foreign land. After a lot of test and questions, the officer that is in front of you asks you to solve a puzzle made of wood, if you don't solve it, you'll probably be rejected and you'll have to come back to Europe...

https://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/puzzle-given-ellis-island-immigrants-test-intelligence-180962779/

This is the reality of this puzzle, a piece of history that show us one of the faces of the reality of the millions of immigrants that arrives at Ellis. It seems simple, just a toy, and at the same time, it's a symbol of too many things. This attracts me to do this simple replica and think about we did and we are doing in our modern societies

title: Samsung Galaxy Note 8 and Gear S3 Wireless Charging Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I remixed two other projects into this pretty sharp little stand. I'm very happy with how it came out.

After combining the Galaxy Charger Stand with the S3 Stand, I modified the galaxy station to better fit the Samsung Wireless Charger model EP-PG950, the wireless charger that Samsung gave away with all Note 8 preorders. I aligned it so it better sits against the phone's sweet spot, so there's no messing about trying to line up the phone to make it charge. I also made more room to pass through the charging cable.
The only change I made to the S3 station was to add a hole for the charging indicator light to be seen through.
