author: UniversalMaker

title: MyRCCar 1/10 Truggy Build for FJ Cruiser Body

description.text:
This is the set of MyRCCar parts needed to build something like a 1/10 Truggy to use 3D printed FJ Cruiser Body, so you could expect something similar to the rc car in the photos.

The selected parts will make a 270 mm wheelbase car with a width of about 300 mm from outside of one wheel to the outside of the other wheel of the axle when using Truggy wheels. This wheels use to be about 110mm in diameter and 50mm width.

Also caster is important to fit the FJ Cruiser body with the pre-made body holders. You must build a front axle with 6º caster and a rear one with 0º caster. This way you can expect the same position of the body relative to the chassis, so you will have all the clearance needed for the truggy wheels.

The goal of this proyect is to build a hobby-level car, not a toy at all. You can expect a very good behavour from the car if you don't crash it continuously. Plastic is plastic. You can do thicker parts but never expect a similar resistance like the one of metal parts with the same size.

I tryed to size car parts so their resistance is good enough for "light-bashing" (not big jumps) or maybe racing if your skills are good enough to avoid certain class of impacts. Anyway, if you would like to race against similar not 3d printed rc cars i'm sure you won't need the extra weight of the FJ Cruiser Body or the higher gravity center.

With a sensored brushless motor and esc you can use it in a similar way to a crawler, really slow motion and good torque but also run at 50-60 Km/h with a 4000kv brushless motor and the right pinion.

In the end... you will have to buy some parts, maybe more than you initially expect. Anyway MyRCCar has been designed to use as less as possible sourced parts, but knowing the most important ones must be bought to have a hobby-level RC car.

MyRCCar offers on its own a good quantity of customization possibilities, as choosing wheelbase, width, caster, camber, "toe-ing", centered or "sided" central diff, but most important of all is that it's designed to fit good but cheap and easy to find sourced parts.

But market changes, good cheap sourced parts will be others in the future probably, so... expected lifetime for your MyRCCar?¿? As plastic is weaker than metal, you will probably break plastic parts you can print again. Anyway, if this "good-cheap" sourced parts change in the future, MyRCCar can change as well.

If there is enough interest in the proyect i'll be delighted to do part of this future work, but I hope the community also contributes through new and better designs and remixes. This would be the key of the question, the way you can do MyRCCar yours.

WHAT IS NEEDED?¿?

Are you decided to enter hobby-level?¿? Remember you can buy a complete car and forget about all this. This is about making your RC car YOURS and unique if you want.

Why i say this of hobby-level?¿? Because the electric components you have to buy are hobby-level, so expect to spend some bucks.

List of mechanical sourced parts
  • 2x HSP 02024 (FR Differentials)
  • 4x HSP 166015 (CVDs). You can use alternatively HSP 106015 changing Steering Block Type
  • 12x 5x10x4 bearings (for wheels, F/R Diff. pinions and steering system)
  • 8x 10x15x4 bearings (for wheels and for F/R diffs if they come without them)
  • 1x Center Differential (You must choose one of the next):
    • HSP 02024 (you will need the converter to use this one and 2 extra 10x15x4 bearings)
    • SST09304 (i think this 1/8 Mod1 T46 diff is the best of the three, but mine came without the needed 12x18x5mm bearings)
    • Trooper Diff from Hobbyking (in plastic or metal version Mod1 44T)
  • 4x Truggy wheels
  • 4x 80 to 100 mm shocks (they can be big bore ones)
  • 4x Wheel Hex (they should come with the 2x10mm pin)
  • 2x HSP adecuated dogbone (for central transmission if you don't want to make them yourself)
  • 6x Ball Joint 5mm head with M3 screw if you don't want to buy Adjustable Steering Pins and for servo arm. I plan to make an adjustable "link" to use in uplinks of suspension and also in steering pins and i think they would use this ball joints.

It would be ideal that you could buy all this things in the same store. I think i have seen some sellers in alixpress wich would send to spain in 18 days. Maybe some other seller is quick to deliver to your country.

An alternative way to get this parts is what i did. I bought a car kit wich included many of them. It was a quanum vandal, but i think now is discontinued, so you should look for another cheap kit wich would include al less the 02024 or similar F/R diffs, the bearings, the shocks, and maybe some wheels if you choose a truggy o monster. I got Buggy wheels with my vandal. I paid about 60€ for the kit and including the electronics in hobbyking i paid about 170€ i think. Also this way i had the opportunity to test the vandal so i could judge MyRCCar in comparison with it.

List of electrical sourced parts
  • 1x 2 Channel Radio and reciever
  • 1x Aprox. 10Kg standard size servo
  • 1x Brushed or brushless motor (big price difference)
  • 1x Electronic Speed Controller (ESC), must match the motor
  • 1x 2S LiPo Battery (Max. Size 150x50x28)
  • 1x LiPo Battery Charger
  • 1x Battery connector adaptor (maybe you need one, think it twice)
  • 1x Led light kit (optional)
  • 1x Double sided tape (recommended)

If you are not sure if "hobby-level" is for you but you want to give it a try, buy a cheap brushed motor and a brushed ESC. With this components, a cheap servo,a 2200mAh battery and a cheap radio and charger you can expect to pay around 42€ in hobbyking.

If, in the other side, you feel confortable about spending some extra bucks in a good electronic kit (it will also be usefull for a not 3D printed rc car), then you can also buy a decent brushless motor (sensored or not) and a matching ESC, a 5000mah, a stronger servo an better charger and radio for about 100€ in Hobbyking too...

The max speed of the car will be related to the tyres you choose, the center differencial and pinion you select but also to the motor max revolutions. This is known as the KV parameter in brushless motors. As a start point for calculations i recommend a motor from 3000 to 4000 KV if you want to run a little fast, and less if you plan to "crawl". Also just changing the pinion you change the gear reduction general ratio. If you are interested in the max speed calculations you can visit RC-Calculations or we can discuse it in the related MyRCCar Group

Other Hardware needed
  • 5 mm Piano Wire to make diff pinion shafts (2x 27mm) and to make central transmission dogbones (2x __mm, depends of your center diff)
  • 3 mm Piano Wire for the pins of the lower arms (4x 54mm and 4x 33mm) and pins of dogbones (4x 12mm)
  • Multi-rotary tool as a dremel (to cut, sand and drill piano wires and maybe your hand)
  • Soldering iron if you have to make some magic with electronics
  • Good little allen tools for M3 screws (1.5, 2 and 2.5 mm allen) if you plan to use hex screws or maybe a good philips screwdriver
  • SCREWS:
    • Countersunk:
      • 2x M3 8mm
      • 8x M3 10mm
      • 12x M3 12mm
      • 56x M3 16mm
      • 5x M3 30mm
    • Better if Hex Socket Head:
      • 2x M3 8mm
      • 4x M3 12mm
      • 20x M3 16mm
      • 4x M3 20mm
    • Nuts:
      • 10x M3
      • 4x M4

I plan to publish soon "FJ Cruiser body for MyRCCar" including the new adaptors to make it fit this car (done) and i'll try to be as exact with the "needs" so maybe you want to wait a little to "make your bussiness"...

I really hope you enjoy this "thing" :)

Added 11/02/2018

Now you can also print the sides of the chassis into two pieces instead of six (the 2 front, 2 rear and 2 links). I did it this way because i could print it in my 200x200 hotbed for this chassis size and with the hope of doing chassis stronger. Look for the parts at the end of the list.

comments.author: Neradon

comments.text: Hi there :) The length of the dogbones will depend of the central diff you choose to use. For this particular Truggy Build I think they will be both the same length. This could be about 69 mm from pin to pin dogbone (1/10 or 1/8 size) if using 1/8 central diff. and about 74 mm pin to pin if using 02024 with the converter as the central diff (only 1/10 size dogbones). If you find some exact references matching those 69 and 74 pin to pin mm please share with us.

author: AntonioGPS

title: Simple .22LR Box With Sleeve
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple .22LR tray with friction fit sleeve.

This is my first scratch built creation. Built in SketchUp 2017. Several test prints before getting it right. I realize that I could have likely found something like this already on Thingiverse however I need to learn how to do the design work myself since I have just been printing other peoples creations for years. Printed on my Reprapguru Prusa I3 V2 at 150 microns. Tray was printed with 3 perimeters (became 4 after slicing) and 0% infill and the sleeve was printed with 2 perimeters (became 3 after slicing) with 100% infill. I recommend keeping the sleeve solid as it will greatly increase rigidity.

Notes:

The rods are not printable but I used them to align the holes and now to see how it was ment.
The original self locking nuts are still in place but are covered bij the PLA sockel.

The rods are pressing aganst the linear bearing housing and glued with 2 component epoxi and the other end ends under the m5 nutt.
Sand 15mm clean at the ends of the rods for a perfect adhesion.
Glue in the rods on the backside and let it harden, then line out the holes on the front and give it a 1mm little less so that the rods will get some pressure when bolted togetter with epoxy also.

Where for?

This design gives the Ender 4 more stabillity of the bed.

Needed rods!

The rods are carbon 6mm-245mm as sold on the web.

Kossel Delta 3D Printer Onderdelen Parallel Manipulator 6*4mm 245mm Fiber Carbon

title: Zelda 8 bits Inventory menu with items

description.text:
Hey makers, it's dangerous to go alone, take this !

Here is some new old-school stuff for you :)

All these items are removable from the inventory menu frame and can be printed easily without any supports.
To have the good colors, you can as I did change the filament during printing at the good layers. It can be done for the frame too.

As I modeled this on Sketchup, I also joined the SKP file if you want to do some changes.

Have fun and please post your own !

If you don't have a 3D printer, you can buy me one on Etsy :
http://etsy.me/2G2REB8

I was looking for some Zelda-related cool stuff to print on Thingiverse when I saw the model uploaded by dmaccallum.

I found it awesome but something was missing, I feared loosing all that stuff because I can sometimes be messy.

Then I thought that it would be a nice idea to put them in their context as in the game by adding the inventory menu frame.

I also imported all items in sketchup to make some changes according to the frame I modeled.

title: Coffee chute for Breville BCG600 coffee grinder

description.text:
Attachment for Breville BCG600 coffee grinder; for directing grinds into an 8oz glass tumbler.

Its an excellent grinder for the price, but Breville completely overlooked users who want to grind for french press or drip-filter coffee. If you aren't using the espresso portafilter attachment, the grinds fly everywhere. This thing replaces the espresso attachment with a chute to grind directly into a glass cup without making a mess.

I'm actually using the glass receiver from an old Bodum coffee grinder, but a drinking glass works too. A glass receiver drastically cuts down on the static electricity that makes grinding so messy. Surprisingly, the grinds don't seem to stick to the PLA chute either.

description.text:
I like the old fashioned twist-to-set kitchen timers. It's so user friendly, but are not very helpful when it calls to time like 30 seconds for brewing some tea or coffer. On the other hand, I really don't feel like to press some buttons a number of times to set a digital kitchen timer. As a result, I often end up not using my digital timer and get very over brewed coffee and tea.

Anyway, I didn't find product of this kind in stores in Taiwan, so I started to design one my own. (Although I later found some twist-to-set kitchen timers on ebay.)

https://youtu.be/uvLOoPS7oTg

More detailed instructions here:

title: Bluesnap Smart Bluetooth Serial Adapter Case

description.text:
This case provides additional protection to a Bluesnap Smart bluetooth serial adapter module.
Adapter: https://serialio.com/product/bluetooth-serial-adapter/bluetooth-adapters-bluetooth-serial-adapter/bluesnap-smart

I used a female wifi dongle with a gender changer screwed to the printed cover which gave me a male serial port. The jumpers inside the module were also changed to reflect this.
The case provides significant protection compared to the stock case while also making it so no loads are transferred to the circuit board through the serial port. The case also provides some protection against moisture.

(1) Print out all three parts.
Natural PLA is best that way you can still see which LED status lights are on.
(2) Screw mini gender changer to top cover.
(3) Insert a small piece of 3mm filament into the button hole and cut it so it sticks out ~1-1.5mm.
(4) Insert the button into the button hole in the bottom case.
(5) Insert serial wifi adapter into bottom case so power port lines up with access port.
(6) Assemble top cover to bottom cover and bolt together using 4 6X 1/2in metal screws.

description.text: Wall mount for 19 mm / 3/4" chisel

Testing bottle stabiliser
https://youtu.be/Alr-AmQTkI8
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4kYwr-Piehc&feature=youtu.be

I wanted a steadicam that was super cheap, had no batteries, and that I could use with only one hand (For snowboarding). I pretty much copied the design of a regular steadicam but without the centre rotation axis that most steadicams have.

Also it has to be portable for shoving into a suitcase or rucksack, and fit onto the generic go pro extendable poles that everyone already has.

Then optimised that for 3D printing and low cost by doing the following:

Go pro screws directly onto the 3D printed part to avoid snap fittings, and only in a fixed place so you don't have to adjust it.
It uses 608 size skateboard bearings for the movement, these are £1-2 on eBay.
https://www.ebay.co.uk/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=p2380057.m570.l1313.TR0.TRC0.H0.X608+bearings.TRS0&_nkw=608+bearings&_sacat=0

It uses 8mm Aluminium tube for the axles, also around £2 on eBay.
https://www.ebay.co.uk/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_sacat=0&_nkw=8mm+od+aluminium+tube&_blrs=spell_check

It uses an M8 caphead screw to hold the weight on - A coke bottle (or could be anything... use your imagination) with a hole drilled in the lid, and then add enough water to stabilise the camera.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Resolution:

100um

Infill:

50

Notes:

Print "rear inner" and "swing cam gyro" with the 22mm face down on the print bed, this makes the part strong enough to have the bearing pressed into the cutout. A bit of glue on the mating face is also required otherwise the bearing falls out eventually.

Once printed, use an M8 tap on the bottom of "swing cam gyro" to allow you to bolt the weight on.

Shopping list

3 STL files above printed in PLA at 100um
1 x M8 Caphead screw 14mm long
150mm of 8mm O.D Aluminium tube or rod. Or you can use Carbon rod but it is more expensive.

Filling Aid for single capsule size 000 , see the pictures for intended use

no toxic printing materials (PLA) strongly recommended :)

remixed_from.author: sasa
remixed_from.title: Simple rack and pinion code for reusing in other projects

description.text:
I wanted a paste extruder for my Mendel90, but RichRap's version took away some of my x-travel. So I tried to design a new model based on some things i found on thingiverse.
The mounting holes are standard 50mm.
Happy printing! Note:
I had some Issues with the gearratio as my stepper was to weak to operate the extruder. So use a very strong Motor or one with a gearreduction. Another Note:
By now this is only a proof of concept, since I didn't (and most likely won't in the near future) find the time to update this extruder so it actually works. Print at your own risk and feel free to remix ad edit so I don't have to ;-).

For assemble you also need:
-1 M8x40mm hexnut
-1 M8 nylock nut
-1 NEMA17 motor
-5 M3 Nuts
-4 M3 set screws (2 of them max. 6mm long)
-1 M3 screw (~10mm long)
-1 608 bearing
-3 M3 screws to mount the motor
-3 M3 washers for munting Motor
-1 reusable ziptie
-1 3piece 10ml syringe (e.g. BRAUN Omnifix)
  • blunt end/shortened cannula if you want a smaller extrusion.
    I think assembling is rather self explainatory.
    Arrangement on the screw:
    biggear - washer_1.5mm - 608 bearing - washer_5mm - smallgear - nut
    The syringe is held in place by the ziptie on the lower end and on the upper end by the snap fit. The rack replaces the plunger and the rubberpiece is used as the seal.
    The 1 M3 screw is used tune the distance between the rack and the smallgear.

comments.text:
I've modified this to fit a 30ml syringe (25mm diameter) and it works quite well. Had to set the extrusion multiplier to something like 1% though to prevent over extrusion.
The only trouble I have is with the rack not staying in line with the pinion, and causing slips. I think the assembly holding the drive gear to the pinion isn't sturdy enough, so I'm going to add an additional bearing for extra support, and see if it helps.
comments.author: yoursstreuli

comments.text:
cool :-)
I thought about how to add another bearing, but couldn't quite find a good way. So props to you!
Regarding your extrusion multiplier, maybe you want to change the steps/mm rating in your firmware or via Gcode if that's possible. So you don't need to go that low with the multiplier.
Greetings
comments.author: yoursstreuli

comments.text: I also swapped the m3 nut and bolt that holds the rack against the drive gear for a small bearing, which helps it slide past. I used M221 in slic3r custom start g-code to change the 'extrude factor override' - I didn't want to change it in the firmware because I often quick swap between regular and paste extrusion, so don't want to re-flash firmware each time... I found M221 S1.09 works well for my setup, which is about 1% of what it would be for normal extrusion!!

description.text:
This is an actuator designed for use with a motion simulator. With the 1610 ballscrew @24 volts and the recommended motor this actuator should be capable of unloaded speeds in excess of 900mm per second. It is meant for use with the Ampflow e30-150 motor. 1605/1610 x550 ballscrew with BK12 bearing. Two pieces of 20x60x500 vslot extruded aluminum from openbuilds. The bearing is from IGUS part #GFL-25. the shaft coupler is 30x42 with 10mm x 12.7 mm bore. The carrier assembly for use with this actuator can be found here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2781279

THIS PROJECT IS A WIP

more info on this projects progress can be found here: https://www.xsimulator.net/community/threads/6dof-racing-platform-12v-dc-3-6kw-arduino-and-mm-smc3.8479/page-8#post-149821

I am controlling it with a kangaroo, sabertooth 2x60 from dimension engineering ( https://www.dimensionengineering.com/ ) and Simtools motion software ( https://simtools.us/ ).

print_settings.Notes:: Rotate the anchor in your slicer so that the "cleat" is pointing up (orientated the way it will mount on the wall).  The shelf should be rotated "upside-down" such that the top surface is actually on your print bed.  These orientations will require no supports.  This thing will certainly test your bed adhesion.  It's long and skinny, so either use a raft, or substantial brim else one end will curl.

title: Display shelf for lightweight things (floating, French cleat inspired)

description.text: Shelf for VERY lightweight models (most immediately: my growing collection of Metal Earth 3D laser cut models). Design constraint: I wanted no mounting hardware to be visible, but it had to be stronger than double-sided tape. Solution: a French cleat-style floating shelf. Two parts for one shelf system: the anchor to screw onto the wall and a shelf to hang off it. Two shelves sizes are provided: 50mm deep by 250mm long, and 80mm deep by 250mm long. The anchor thing works for either one. Again: this is for LIGHTWEIGHT models; I would not do pull-ups on it or practice your rock climbing skills.

Printer:

Raise3D N2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Rotate the anchor in your slicer so that the "cleat" is pointing up (orientated the way it will mount on the wall). The shelf should be rotated "upside-down" such that the top surface is actually on your print bed. These orientations will require no supports. This thing will certainly test your bed adhesion. It's long and skinny, so either use a raft, or substantial brim else one end will curl.

How to mount

Once printed, examine the anchor and you will notice the counter-sunk through-holes for small screws (sorry I don't know what size they are; it's modeled after what I had around the house, but they're 3/4" long and flat on the top). The cleat goes up and I hung the anchor right into drywall (again: this is for LIGHTWEIGHT model display ONLY!). The shelf "clicks" onto the anchor and "floats" while covering the mounting hardware. Enjoy!

author: mightynozzle

title: Brushless Whoop Mounting Kit for Rakon Heli Delrin Carbon 66mm

description.text:
These are the mounting parts I used for a 16mmx16mm mounting pattern PCB on the Rakon Heli 66mm frame. My stack was the Furious FPV pepperfish ESC, Lumenier tinyFISH, Furious FPV MNOVA VTX.

To install
1) Tap the frame-ESC mount for a M1.2 screw
2) Screw the frame-ESC mount to the frame
3) Feed the M2 bolt through the frame-ESC mount
4) Next stack the spacer-m2-2mm part (this gives the USB on the FC clearance)
5) Stack the FC
6) Stack the spacer-m2-4mm part
7) Stack the VTX
8) Secure with nut
9) Repeat with 3 other screw
10) Fly!

Additional parts needed:

  • x4 M1.2 4mm screws
  • x4 M2 20mm nylon screw
  • x4 M2 nylon nut

title: pulley and wheel with 10mm thread square nut compatibility

description.text:
A coworker was looking for spare parts for his kids projects.

[4.7" diameter] The pulley has a large rounded groove so a rope or band could be used to move it.

[7" diameter) The wheel was modeled after the Harley Davidson (90's) fat boy wheel!

Both have a cut out center of 10mm in diameter with additional space to place a square nut. The wheels have space on both sides to fit 2 square nuts.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.35mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I printed it in PETG. PETG rafts are very messy and easily curl up from the build plate causing the first layer to be ruined. If you have trouble printing the first layer, then use slicer settings to slow down the first layer to only 20% of max speed.

Each Pulley took ~5hrs for a draft resolution.
Each Wheel took ~14hrs for a draft resolution.

title: Printer bed lighting - V-slot 2020 click-mount (Ender-2, CR-10)

description.text:
Lighting of 3D printer bed - primary designed for Ender-2 (CR-7), but usable for any printer with V-slot 2020 horizontal profile.
Dont need screws, mounted by clicking into profile groove (and removable after strong pulling).
Uses strip with 5050 LEDs (10mm width), cuttable by 50 mm - original horizontal part (115 mm - 15mm for connecting cable) is designed for two sections (6 LEDs, 100 mm) and two slot holders, but it is no problem print and use it longer (change lenght in slicer) - and add additional holders to slot.

description.text:
Remixed "Dart Case - created in PARTsolutions by Dape", to support Larger 10mm Grips. The case is a bit longer as well to accommodate longer darts.

0.2mm Layers, w/ Raft.

Behind the Scenes.

I remixed this by loading it up in Tinkercad. I was able to increase the size, and used a empty cylinder to increase the hole for the grips / shafts. I then had to add a another block of material around the mid section where the shafts come out of the housing to make it thick enough.

I then had to redesign the top to fit the new sizes, and ensure it would snap together correctly.

For my personal prints I added the name of the Darts player to each one I printed, this is very easy in Tinkercad, maybe someday I can come back and learn how to use the customizer.

print_settings.Notes:: With the Qi charging module PETG or ABS shall be used to avoid deformation of the box.

description.text:
This is a small LiPo battery powered display console.

Main features:

  • 4.2 inch 400x300 E-Ink E-Paper Display Modul
  • ESP32 Lolin32 board
  • 4 capacitive touch buttons
  • LiPo 3,7V 2000mAh

I am using this device to control some home automation features. It's controlled via the 4 touch buttons, which are used as soft keys. The ESP32 is normally in deep sleep mode and wakes up every minute to update the time, or if any buttons is touched. The communication is based on Bluetooth LE to a central, which provides the characteristics for the current time and status information to be displayed. Further BLE characteristics are available to control the home automation functions.
I have chosen BLE in order to consume less power. A 2000mAh battery should last 10 days.
Optionally a wireless QI receiver module can be used for convenient charging of the LiPo battery.

BoM:

  • LOLIN32 V1.0.0-ESP32.
  • Qi wirles charging receiver module (optional)
  • Waveshare 4.2 inch 400x300 E-Ink E-Paper Display Modul - B/W version to allow fast partial update.
  • LiPo with 2-pin JST-PH connector.
  • 4 thumbtacks
  • Dupont jumper wire - Optionally if you don't want to solder the buttons directly.
  • Screws and Nuts.

Printer:

K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

With the Qi charging module PETG or ABS shall be used to avoid deformation of the box.

Shorten the thumbtack pins with a side cutter so that the remaining pin sticks out about 0.5 mm. Solder the wires with the dupont jumper to the backside of the thumbtacks. The dupont jumper fits to the hole in the lid. Finally glue the thumbtacks together with the lid.

Software:
https://github.com/christof62/status-display
You may use parts of my project and adapt to your needs. I am using the display console to show status information from my home automation server. A Raspberry Pi Zero W, which is installed in the living room works as MQTT to BLE gateway. This is a NodeJS service unsing bleno.
The ESP32 in the display wakes up every minute to update the time. The accuracy of the low frequency clock of the ESP32 is not high. Hence it is required to synchronisiere the clock after every now and then. A BLE connection is established according to the commIntervalls definition in configuration.h. The connection is also established if one of the 4 buttons is touched. After the connection to the service is available, the device receives time and status Information and sends commands if requested.

description.text:
I was looking for a DIY clicker for clicker training cats (yes it is possible). Looking for metal to use I decided to use the end caps from a crescent rolls package (see photos). I placed them ridge-side down on the garage floor, placed a cabinet knob on top and hit the knob with a hammer. This dent allows the cap to make a great clicker that rebounds when pressed. You could use any similar object to dent the caps but make sure to use an object that is maybe 1/3 the diameter of the cap.

I designed the case in TinkerCad and I will say that after clearing the support material out, it is a little tough to push the cap into the base but once in there it is tight. After removing the raft from the top and some light sanding, the top is also tight but requires no glue. I designed the hole to be for a lanyard but also double as holding the two parts together. On the two I have made, the fit is tight and there is nothing else required to hold them together. Enjoy!

Note: The second one I made took a bit of filing/sanding since the lid was a little bent. You may need to do some additional sanding of the inset if there the parts do not fit snug.

Update: I just uploaded V2 of the bottom that has a cleaner path for the disc. This should make it easier to insert.

description.text:
These are 26 and 31 mm wheels for the Vintage tires from Protoform and HPI. I printed the wheels with 6mm brim and full supports. The wheels come off the build plate almost as a solid piece, it takes a bit of effort with a screwdriver and a sharpy to clean them up in my case. On the 26 mm version you can see the print layers since the wheel is very shallow, on the 31 mm version it looks better. On the picture you see a set fitted to a Tamiya TT-02 chassis, I gues they will fit pretty much any touring car chassis. The 26 mm wheel weighs 11 grams, the 31 mm version weighs 14 grams. Both according to Cura, I didn't put them on a scale.

Of all wheels I included the FreeCAD files and STP files for you to mod, and STLs if you just want to print them.

[EDIT] Feb 11-2018: added wheel nuts to the wheel flanges, just basic little cylinders like on the Protoform rims[/EDIT]

Have fun with them!

title: Belt Tensioner for Ender2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
remix of fessyFOO´s Belt Tensioner for Creality Ender2 X (20x20 profile) and Y-axis (20x40 profile)

The parts are meant to be used with the original pulleys.

The pulleys are a 2part design with 8mm ID and an overallwidth of 10mm.
Insert the spacer (Spacer_-_ID5_OD8_L10) and you end up with a pulley for 5mm axis.
I took some Ikea "cabinet joiner" with 5MM OD and a length of ~24mm, shortened them to 20mm and used them as axis.
The puller is designed accordingly: 5(mm)a(xis)8(mm)b(earing)10(mm)h(ead)
The Tensioner Cases offset the pulley by 3mm for better belt alignment.

The Nuts to make the actual tensioning happen are at 97%,98% and 99% of the original.

The quote was printed in two colours Polysmooth (Snow white and Jet black), and glued to the stand with isopropanol. If you don't have a dual extruder printer you can still merge the 2 texts and print the first 1 mm in one colour, change the fillament and continue to print the next 0.5 mm in a second colour, and the remaining 0.5 mm in the first colour again.

The design works a bit like laser cut designs, and need to be assembled. You need to print the 5 legs, the ring, the connector and the dual colour text1 and text2. The latter needs to be glued to the connector (since I used PolySmooth, I used isopropanol to soften the plastic and glue them together).

This is a dog.

Modeled for a water tower made out of a can for crushed tomato. The shape is calculated to match this one type of a can (seems quite standard). The file contains four pillars. The bottom of the pillars have a little support, but it is easily removable. The thin support between the crossbeams didn't really print out, but it did the job. I printed it with Ultimaker 2+ and used Cura for the slicing.

I will add photos of the finished water tower after I get some paint on it.

Imperial Eagle -logo copyrights belong to Games Workshop.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

After..

Had to do some carving with a knife and sanding with a nail file. The rugged look works fine for a battle worn water tower.

Planning and modeling

First I had to remember some math and learn how to calculate the length and the curvature of
the end wall a sector. Or some such, math in english isn't my strong point, but I think you can get the idea. Then I used Inkscape to make a drawing with the exact measurements. I imported the basic shape to Tinkercad and then went on to make the pillars. Just basic stuff with holes and shapes. The eagle is made with Inkscape and imported to Tinkercad.

I created this thing in need of a solution for a bowden extruder.
It works great with satoer's Bowden tube feeder:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:159159 The design works with the original Solidoodle nozzle and the J-head Mk5. Haven't tried it for any others.
You can change the size of the bowden connector within the C4d file

Voici un organisateur et un distributeur de recharge Montana (ou autre chose d'un diamètre de 25mm).
Prochainement mise a jour pour les canettes 33cl et pour les épices de cuisine.

Pour l'assemblage complet il vous faut imprimer les pièces suivantes:

  • 1x "base"
  • 1x "contour"
  • 2x "engrenage 1"
  • 1x "engrenage 2"
  • 1x "cache engrenage"
  • 1x "centre"

Suivant votre besoin vous pouvez changer l'échelle du contour (uniquement sur la hauteur).

Vous pouvez également empiler les ensembles pour avoir plusieurs distributeurs.

Ceci est un premier design qui est fonctionnel chez moi. Vous pouvez laisser des commentaires si vous voulez une modification au système.

description.text: The wire I use to rebuild my antennas is pretty soft so I made this up so that they don't get crushed in my flight bag. In case anyone wonders using soft wire for antennas is great as they just get bent up when you crash. You straighten them back out by hand and keep flying. I have had to rebuild a lot less antennas doing this so far. Only downside is they don't travel well which is why I made this.

description.text:
Use this to design your own printer mods such as z probe mounts, fan shrouds, etc.

This is a model of MY Creality Ender 2 x-axis carriage plate. It is reasonable to assume that your Creality printer has a very similar plate but it is possible (even likely) that manufacturing variations may mean your plate is not identical to this one - be sure to check the placement of all mounting holes (and the length of the hotend mounting posts) before investing significant effort designing your next fantastic printer mod!

For a good hotend model search GrabCAD for "Creality CR 10 Hotend"
The mounting holes are not quite aligned with this plate but it's close enough ;)

Feb 24, 2018
I've added a simplified version of the model with no modeled threads with a lower poly density.

Also, I've shared a tinkercad drawing of this this simplified model at https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cPkxiBMnMX8 ... tinkercad has problems with the geometry but it should be usable enough for use as a canvas for your designs.

Mar 11, 2018
Added an STL of just the plate, no wheels or screws.

description.text:
Yet another model that paid a visit to the model doctor…
This is a remix of budgiesarecool's letter opener in the shape of a pocket knife, with the following minor improvements to make it easier to print:

  • Finally the correct scale (why everyone kept the wrong scale in their remixes, beats me…)
  • Manifold models (thanks to MasonIsLegit)
  • Everything is positioned in the best orientation for printing.
  • The pin and hole are 4 mm diameter. This makes it easier to ream the hole with a 4 mm drill if needed.
  • Two variations on the pin, one narrower and one fatter, such that you can pick the one that fits best (tip: print all 3 of them at the same time, this will avoid that the filament melts into a messy blob).
  • A variation on the handle that has a less steep overhang, this makes it easier to print without needing either supports or a lot of cooling.
  • Slightly tighter tolerances, to make it less sloppy.

And yes, it will probably cut thru cardboard if you print it with sufficiently hard filament! :P

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I printed everything with 3 perimeters for increased strength. You may want to print the blade at 100% infill to make it less flexible. The only real reason why I used glow-in-the-dark PLA for the blade, is because it is about the hardest filament I have (of course, being able to open letters in the dark is also cool).

You shouldn't need supports, especially not if you print the handle with milder overhangs. Even the original one can be printed without supports if you apply sufficient cooling.

Should even the ‘fatter’ pin still be too loose, simply scale it up by one or two percent until it fits snugly.
